metadata.title: Mathematical modeling of cytotoxicity of metal oxide nanoparticles using the index of ideality correlation criteria

sections.heading: Journal Pre-proof
sections.text: Mathematical modeling of cytotoxicity of metal oxide nanoparticles using the index of ideality correlation criteria

sections.heading: Shahin Ahmadi
sections.text:
PII: S0045-6535(19)32432-4 DOI: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.chemosphere.2019.125192 Reference: CHEM 125192
To appear in: ECSN

sections.heading: Accepted Date: 21 October 2019
sections.text:
Please cite this article as: Ahmadi, S., Mathematical modeling of cytotoxicity of metal oxide nanoparticles using the index of ideality correlation criteria, Chemosphere (2019), doi: https:// doi.org/10.1016/j.chemosphere.2019.125192.
This is a PDF file of an article that has undergone enhancements after acceptance, such as the addition of a cover page and metadata, and formatting for readability, but it is not yet the definitive version of record. This version will undergo additional copyediting, typesetting and review before it is published in its final form, but we are providing this version to give early visibility of the article. 1
Mathematical modeling of cytotoxicity of metal oxide nanoparticles using the index of ideality 1
correlation criteria 2 Shahin Ahmadi* 3
Department of Chemistry, Kermanshah Branch, Islamic Azad University, Kermanshah, Iran 4
Abstract: 5
Several types of metal oxide nanoparticles (MO-NPs) are often utilized as one of the novel class 6
of materials in the pharmaceutical industry and human health. The wide use of MO-NPs 7
forces an enhanced understanding of their potential impact on human health and the 8
environment. The research aims to investigate and develop a nano-QFAR (nano- quantitative 9
feature activity relationship) model applying the quasi-SMILES such as cell line, assay, time 10
exposition, concentration, nanoparticles size and metal oxide type for prediction of cell viability 11
(%) of MO-NPs. The total set of 83 quasi-SMILES of MO-NPs divided into training, validation 12
and test sets randomly three times. The statistical model results based on the balance of 13
correlation target function (TF1) and index of ideality correlation target function (TF2) and the 14
Monte Carlo optimization were compared. The comparison of two target function results 15
indicated that TF2 improves the predictability of models. The significance of various eclectic 16
features of both increase and decrease of cell viability (%) is provided. Mechanistic 17
interpretation of significant factors for the model are proposed as well. The sufficient statistical 18
quality of three nano-QFAR models based on TF2 reveals that the developed models can be 19
efficiency for predictions of the cell viability (%) of MO-NPs. 20
* Corresponding author email: ahmadi.chemometrics@gmail.com
2
Keywords: Nano-QFAR, Metal oxide nanoparticles, Cell viability, Quasi-SMILES, Index of 21
ideality correlation 22
23

sections.heading: 1. Introduction 24
sections.text:
Nanotechnology denotes the knowledge from the field of physics, chemistry, medicine, biology, 25
and technology of nano devices, which has been receiving considerable attention because of its 26
capability to create nanoparticles (NPs) or nanodevices with dimensions between 1-100 nm size 27
range (Olawoyin 2018). The larger specific surface area of NPs compared with their bulk 28
counterparts induce unique properties (Karlsson, Gustafsson et al. 2009). Metal oxide 29
nanoparticles (MO-NPs) has drawn significant attention for their different applications ranging 30
from medical healthcare (Hu, Culloty et al. 2014, Shetti, Bukkitgar et al. 2019), drug delivery 31
(Panda, Satapathy et al. 2019), sensors (Najafi, Zolghadr et al. 2019), and optoelectronics (Cano-32
Franco and Álvarez-Láinez 2019) to environmental remediation (Wu, Li et al. 2015). 33
Quantitative feature-activity/toxicity relationships (QFAR/QFTR) for reliable prediction of 34
biochemical activity and toxicity of nanomaterials is useful knowledge for synthesis and 35
development of new nanomaterials and nanotechnologies (Toropov, Toropova et al. 2012, 36
Toropova and Toropov 2013, Manganelli, Leone et al. 2016, Pan, Li et al. 2016, Toropova and 37
Toropov 2017, Leone, Bertuzzi et al. 2018, Hataminia, Noroozi et al. 2019). Nowadays, research 38
on biomedical and health-care applications of MO-NPs is increasing rapidly (Mu, Zhao et al. 39
2017, Bogusz, Tehei et al. 2018, Sruthi, Ashtami et al. 2018, Nallendran, Selvan et al. 2019, 40
Qiao, Xiao et al. 2019). The different MO-NPs have also shown the potential to be utilized in the 41
treatment of highly radioresistant cancer cells (Hosseini, Mirrahimi et al. 2018, Rękorajska, 42
Cichowicz et al. 2019). Moreover, in the most effective chemotherapy of cancer, cell viability is 43
3
one of the fundamental factors for predicting radiosensitivity in the treatment of cancer (Rödel, 44
Hoffmann et al. 2005). 45
Due to increased growth of literature on nanomaterials and in vitro cytotoxicity tests, there is an 46
urgent need to a comprehensive knowledge of how the nanomaterials interact with biological 47
systems to design safe and practical nanomaterials. However, cytotoxicity tests are time- 48
and resource-consuming, which is why researchers are developing computational models to 49
predict the behavior of nanomaterials in biological systems. Such predictor models would allow 50
researchers to design experiments, streamline and prioritize tests on real nanomaterials. 51
The CORAL software is a very user friend and free software for the building of QSAR and nano-52
QFAR models (Gobbi, Beeg et al. 2016, Ahmadi and Akbari 2018, Ahmadi, Mardinia et al. 53
2019, Ahmadi, Mehrabi et al. 2019, Choi, Trinh et al. 2019). This package use quasi-SMILES 54
describing both the physicochemical features and experimental conditions (not only information 55
regarding the molecular structure) and Monte Carlo optimization to develop the predictive nano-56
QFAR models for activity and cytotoxicity of nanomaterials (Manganelli, Leone et al. 2016, 57
Manganelli and Benfenati 2017). 58
This study was designed to explore and build a mathematical model using the combination of 59
some quasi-SMILES such as cell line, assay, time exposition, concentration and metal oxide size 60
and type as eclectic information in the construction of QFAR model for prediction of cell 61
viability (%) of MO-NPs. The statistical results of QFAR models based on two different target 62
functions of CORAL software that called the balance of correlation target function (TF1) and 63
index of ideality correlation target function (TF2) using the Monte Carlo optimization were 64
compared. 65
66
4

sections.heading: 2.1. Data set collecting 68
sections.text:
The required data of cell viability (%) for human breast cancer cell line MCF-7, human 69
fibrosarcoma cell line HT-1080, human liver carcinoma cell line HepG2, 70
human colon carcinoma cells HT-29 and rat adrenal pheochromocytoma cell line PC-12 were 71
gathered from in vitro data published in new peer-reviewed papers (Liu, Xu et al. 2010, Ahmad, 72
Ahamed et al. 2012, Ahamed, Ali et al. 2013, Wahab, Siddiqui et al. 2014, Ahamed, Akhtar et al. 73
2018, Miri and Sarani 2018, Ahamed, Akhtar et al. 2019, Alhadlaq, Akhtar et al. 2019, 74
Ibraheem, Aziz et al. 2019). The cell viability (%) of metal oxide nanoparticles SnO2, MnO2, 75
ZnO, Bi2O3, NiO, CeO2, SiO2 and TiO2 in different experimental condition was used as a 76 dependent variable. Table 1 indicates the codes utilized for different cell lines, methods, time 77
exposition, concentration and type and size of the metal oxide of the invitro data, their quasi-SMILES 78
and the value of cell viability (%). For developing and validating of the QFAR models, the total 79
set is divided into four categories of the training set (≈35%), invisible training set (≈35 %), 80
calibration set (≈15 %) and validation set (≈15 %), randomly. For checkup the proposed 81
approach, three different splits are investigated. 82
The CORAL utilizes from the training data to develop the QFAR model. The invisible training 83
set is used to prevent the overtraining of the model during the construction of it, while the 84
calibration set is employed for optimization of T and N parameters. The validation set as the 85
compounds that did not have any role in creating the model is utilized for verification of the 86
predictability of the constructed model. 87
88
2.2. Quasi-SMILES definition 89
Quasi-SMILES is a string of codes that describes the physicochemical properties and/or 90
experimental conditions as an expansion of the traditional SMILES. Quasi-SMILES utilized here 91 are cell line, toxic assay method, time exposition (h), NPs concentration (µg mL-1), NPs size 92
(nm) and metal oxide type. An alphabet or number was employed to create the quasi-SMILES. 93
6
Latin alphabet from ‘H’ to ‘L’ is utilized to specify the cell line; alphabet ‘M’ and ‘N’ were used 97
for 3-(4,5-dimethylthiazol-2-yl)-2,5-diphenyltetrazolium bromide (MTT) and the neutral red 98
uptake (NRU) assay, respectively; alphabet ‘X’, ‘Y’ and ‘Z’ was employed for time exposition 99 of 24, 48 and 72 h; alphabet from ‘A’ to ‘F’ was used to define the NPs concentration (µg mL-1); 100
alphabet from ‘P’ to ‘T’ was utilized to determine normalized NPs size, and number 1 to 8 was 101
used for metal oxide type. Table 1 provides the physicochemical features and biochemical 102
conditions for MO-NPs. the following normalization equation is implemented to generate codes 103
of the normalized NPs size (the particle size of MO-NPs varied from 13 to 97 nm), which was 104
first defined in previously published studies (Toropova, Toropov et al. 2014, Choi, Trinh et al. 105
2019). 106

2.3. Nano-QFAR modeling 118
7
The reliable models in this research were constructed using quasi-SMILES for prediction of the 119
effect of several types of MO-NPs on cell viability of different cell types according to the 120
following equations (Choi, Trinh et al. 2019): 121 Cell viability (%) = C+ + C- × DCW(1∗, 4∗) 122 (2) 123
where C0 and C1 are the constant value and DCW(T, N) is the summation of the correlation 124
weight for all attribute Ak in each Quasi-SMILES and was calculated according to the following 125
equation: 126
DCW(T, N) = ∑ CW(A ) 8- (3) 127 where Ak is kth attribute of a MO-NPs (Table 1); the CW(Ak) denotes the correlation weight of 128
the kth descriptor. The correlation weights for different features were obtained by the Monte 129
Carlo method optimization and the correlation weights for the optimum T and Nis utilized for 130
prediction of cell viability (%). 131
There are two target functions for the building of QSAR model in CORAL software: target 132
function based on the balance of correlation (TF1) and target function based on the index of 133
ideality (TF2) (Toropov and Toropova 2017). 134 TF- = R;<= + R ;<= − |R;<= − R ;<=| × c (4) 135 where R;<= and R ;<= are correlation coefficients between experimental and predicted values of 136 cell viability (%) for the training and invisible training sets, respectively and c denotes an 137
empirical constant. In this study, TF2 has been used (Toropov and Toropova 2017): 138 TFA = TF- + IIC (5) 139 where IIC (index of the ideality of correlation) criteria is obtained by the equation (6): 140

Here, we defined the values of T and N from 1 to 5 and 1-15 respectively. 153
After searching of the response surface of TF2 for the validation set, T* and N* with the 154
maximum value of TF2 for cell viability and DCW(T*,N*) is obtained. 155
156
2.4. The applicability domain of the model 157
One of the OECD concepts for model validation needs demonstrating the applicability domain 158
(AD) for the QSAR models (Toropova and Toropov 2017, Gómez-Jiménez, Gonzalez-Ponce et 159
al. 2018), which is a theoretical region in chemical space where the model can be employed and 160
is constructed using the “Defect[\! O]F^EG]” as in equation (10) (Toropova and Toropov 2017, 161
Toropov and Toropova 2019): 162
DefectD_ = |`abc(D_)O`HIJ(D_)|

NTRN(Ak) shows the frequency of quasi-SMILES including Ak in the training set; NTRN denotes the 173
total frequency of quasi-SMILES in the training set; NCAL(Ak) is the frequency of quasi-SMILES 174
including Ak in the calibration set and NCAL indicates the total number of quasi-SMILES in the 175
calibration set. 176
Equation (10) is utilized to demonstrate the domain of applicability and distinguish the outliers. 177
Thus, at the ideal condition Defect[\! O]F^EG] is zero, i.e. when the chance of Ak in quasi-178
SMILES of the training set and the calibration set is equal. Generally, it does not happen and in 179
the optimization process of the QFAR model the statistical features improve when equation (14) 180
is fulfilled (Toropova and Toropov 2017): 181 Defect[\! O]F^EG] = ∑ DefectD_ D_ 8- (13) 182 By quasi-SMILES the substance codified is embedded in the domain of the applicability if: 183 Defect[\! O]F^EG] < 2 × Defectiiiiiiii[\! O]F^EG] (14) 184

where Defectiiiiiiii[\! O]F^EG] denotes the average of the Defect[\! O]F^EG] values for the training 185
set. 186

3. Results and discussion 188
3.1. QFAR models 189
The QFAR models were created for the prediction of the cell viability (%) of different cell types 190
which exposed to several types of MO-NPs. Three splits of 83 quasi-SMILES are developed 191
based on the Monte Carlo optimization and two different target function (TF1 and TF2) and 192
indicated in Eqs. 15 to 20: 193
Constructed models based on TF1: 194
Split 1 195
Cell viability (%) = 14.9257 (±0.4058) + 19.4082 (±0.1739) × DCW(1, 2) 196
(15) 197
Split 2 198
Cell viability (%) = 40.8750 (±0.3970) + 14.8555 (±0.1523) × DCW(1,7) 199
(16) 200
Split 3 201
Cell viability (%) = 36.3887 (±0.4322) + 20.0730 (±0.2239) × DCW(1, 3) 202
(17) 203
Constructed models based on TF2: 204
Split 1 205
Cell viability (%) = 47.94889 (±0.3884) + 21.1778(±0.2219) × DCW(1, 3) 206
(18) 207
11
Split 2 208
Cell viability (%) = 35.1584 (±0.4403) + 34.4495 (±0.3327) × DCW(2, 5) 209
(19) 210
Split 3 211
Cell viability (%) = 28.0288 (±0.5825) + 16.1180 (±0.1965) × DCW(1, 4) 212
(20) 213
The reliable above statistical equations are utilized for prediction of cell viability (%) of different 214
cell types exposed to MO-NPs. Table 3 reports the important characteristics of QFAR models 215 achieved from Eqs. 15 to 20. The statistical parameters such as R2, Q2, MAE, RMSEP, CCC, IIC 216
and F were calculated to investigate the predictability and robustness of the QFAR models. The 217
mathematical equations for calculating of the statistical parameters indicated in Table S1 ((see 218
Supplementary material). The satisfactory statistical results of models for different sets of these 219
models and are indicated in Table 3. 220

statistical criteria for the training and invisible training set, but the QFAR model is very good for 229
the calibration and validation sets. 230

3.2. Mechanistic interpretation 258
We can obtain a group of features by calculating the correlation weights of each feature under 259
several attempts, which are distinguished promoters of increasing or decreasing the cell viability 260
(%) in all three splits. Table 6 indicates promoters of increasing or decreasing the cell viability. 261
As the results of Table 6, the cytotoxicity of MO-NPs on breast cancer cell lines (MCF-7) is the 262
least among the other studied cell lines. More ever, the cell viability increased by low 263
16
concentration (5, 10 and 25 µg mL-1) and decrease by high concentration (200 µg mL-1). The 264
shorter exposure time (24 h) increase cell viability. In general, these computational results reveal 265
that the proposed model is operating appropriately. Based on the increase/decrease promoter 266
results, the SnO2, MnO2, and SiO2 NPs are the least toxic MO-NPs among all the eight MO-NPs 267
but ZnO is the most toxic MO-NPs with the lowest cell viability, this result is also in the same 268
direction with the experimental results in other literature that indicate the metal oxide 269
Increase H........... Cell line MCF-7 X........... Time exposition (h) 24 1........... Metal oxide type SnO2 2........... Metal oxide type MnO2 7........... Metal oxide type SiO2 A........... Concentration (µg mL-1) 5 B........... Concentration (µg mL-1) 10 C........... Concentration (µg mL-1) 25
17
Decrease F........... Concentration (µg mL-1) 200 3........... Metal oxide type ZnO
280 4. Conclusion 281
In the current research, quasi-QFAR modeling was utilized to predict the cell viability (%) of 282 MCF-7, HT1080, HepG2, HT-29 and PC12 cells exposed to 8 metal oxide nanoparticles. All 283 quasi-QFAR models constructed based on Monte Carlo optimization by two target function 284 named balance of correlation (TF1) and index of ideality correlation (TF2) and the model results 285 were compared. These results confirmed that TF2 improve the predictability of models and 286 consequently, the simple and predictive models can be applied for prediction of cytotoxicity of 287 metal oxide nanoparticles on different cell lines. As a result of QFAR model, the most important 288 features increasing and decreasing cell viability (%) introduced that they agree with the 289 experimental results in peer-reviewed literature. Due to increased growth of publications on in 290 vitro cytotoxicity of metal oxides, this model can be extended and revised for other cell lines and 291 different metal oxide nanoparticles in future. 292 293 Acknowledgements 294 The author would like to thank Dr Andrey A. Toropov and Dr Alla P. Toropova for their expert 295 advice and providing CORAL software. 296 297

Highlights
• The predictive model for the cell viability of metal oxide nanoparticles is developed.
• The Quasi-SMILES and IIC criteria are utilized for model building.
• The Quasi-SMILES describing physicochemical features and experimental conditions.
• The predictive quality of models for metal oxide nanoparticles is satisfied.

Also, the robustness of QFAR modeling based on TF2 236 checked by Y-randomization tests and correlation coefficient for different sets after several Y237 randomization tests were indicated in Table 5 (Ahmadi and Akbari 2018).

metadata.abstractText: 5 Several types of metal oxide nanoparticles (MO-NPs) are often utilized as one of the novel class 6 of materials in the pharmaceutical industry and human health. The wide use of MO-NPs 7 forces an enhanced understanding of their potential impact on human health and the 8 environment. The research aims to investigate and develop a nano-QFAR (nanoquantitative 9 feature activity relationship) model applying the quasi-SMILES such as cell line, assay, time 10 exposition, concentration, nanoparticles size and metal oxide type for prediction of cell viability 11 (%) of MO-NPs. The total set of 83 quasi-SMILES of MO-NPs divided into training, validation 12 and test sets randomly three times. The statistical model results based on the balance of 13 correlation target function (TF1) and index of ideality correlation target function (TF2) and the 14 Monte Carlo optimization were compared. The comparison of two target function results 15 indicated that TF2 improves the predictability of models. The significance of various eclectic 16 features of both increase and decrease of cell viability (%) is provided. Mechanistic 17 interpretation of significant factors for the model are proposed as well. The sufficient statistical 18 quality of three nano-QFAR models based on TF2 reveals that the developed models can be 19 efficiency for predictions of the cell viability (%) of MO-NPs. 20 * Corresponding author email: ahmadi.chemometrics@gmail.com
metadata.creator: Elsevier
